text:
Thank you, [? Allison, ?] for
the really nice introduction. And thank you all for
coming to the seminar. I'm really excited to
be here with you today.

So yeah, I am the director
of the Material Robotics Lab here at BU.

And I'm excited
to be telling you a little bit about the
research that we have going on.

Now, we've been at BU
for about five years. So I want to start with
what really motivates me

and my students to wake up every
morning, and get into the lab, and do work, and keep
ourselves, I guess, motivated,

which is solving open societal
challenges in health care, so addressing open
societal challenges

when it comes to
making robots that can enable easier, more
Intuitive surgical procedures

to perform and also enable new
surgical procedures that are not possible to perform today.

Maybe some of you are
familiar with the idea of open surgery, where
basically a patient is

going to be literally cut open. And the surgeon
has full awareness

of what is going on within
the surgical environment. So they have direct
visualization

of the environment,
direct haptic feedback because they can
touch the organs and they can feel
what is going on.

But really, what
we want to do is move towards more of a minimally
invasive surgical scenario,

where you don't really have
to perform cuts to access the surgical target area.

But you navigate to that
surgical target area in a minimally
invasive way, which

means that you are
accessing the target area through natural
orifices, for example.

So think about navigating
through to the brain by accessing your nostrils or
accessing through the mouth

and reaching the lungs
and going and exploring the lungs to look
for a tumor or take a biopsy, that type of thing.

So this is great
because patients don't have any postoperative
complications-- scarring, infections.

And they basically can walk
outside of the operating room the same day.

However, there are
many other problems associated with
this, which basically

have to deal with the complexity
of performing that procedure. So surgeons have to
undergo years of training

because steering and controlling
these flexible instruments is a little bit more
complicated to do.

And so we want to
build robots that can do these procedures better
and help surgeons perform

their day-to-day job better,
return some level of information

that they don't really have, and
return some levels of dexterity at the distal end of
those instrumentation.

So you have to imagine like,
if you want to control a hose and you want to control the
flexible tip of that instrument,

it's really difficult
to do it when you have such long, flexible
instruments, like endoscopes

for example. And so these clinical
applications, these medical
applications, I would say,

really give us the
opportunity of-- these are case studies that are
really good for roboticists,

like engineers,
roboticists like myself, because we are really interested
in solving fundamental questions

and open challenges in
robotics associated, for example, with
robotic navigation, robotic manipulation.

So for instance, what
is more challenging than navigating into
environments like these ones?

The colon is a
very unstructured, flexible environment. When you have a robot navigating
through, it stretches and moves.

And same thing here. Navigating inside the
lungs, it's really difficult because it's a maze of very
different, I would say,

tubes, branches of bronchi
that you have to navigate into to get to the location where the
tumor is located, for example.

And so navigation is a
really challenging problem in these fields, in these
application scenarios,

manipulation too. You can think of you want
to access a tumor located

in the brain, maybe in
a deep seated location within the brain. And you want to
remove that tumor.

But how are you going
to be doing that, preserving the healthy
tissue surrounding the brain?

Because at the end
of the day, yes, you want to treat
the tumor, but you don't want that patient to
wake up with some narrow motor

functionalities
impaired or narrow cognitive functionalities.
and it's super crucial how you interact and
manipulate the brain tissue.

And so these are all
really great case studies that allow us to tackle
fundamental robotics

challenges, especially
related to how we are going to be building these robots.

My lab is really hardware
design-focused because we cannot

really buy a commercial robot
and just use that for these

types of applications. Our focus on a day-to-day basis
is talk to our collaborators, talk to our surgeon that
are collaborating with us,

understand the clinical problems
that they have on a daily basis, and engineer a robotic
solution to it.

So we have to start from
scratch when we do that. And sometimes, this
also means that we have to develop the
manufacturing technologies

to build these robots. And so we have to
think about how we are going to be building
actuators and sensors, how we're

going to be manufacturing
them and integrating them inside our robots. And we have to think
about how these robots are

going to transmit
forces onto the tissue. We want to have effective
robotic systems to do that.

And so in my lab, we have been
investigating three classes of different soft surgical
robots to do that,

which are soft continuum
robots, soft reactive skins-- and in this part of the talk,
I'm going to be focusing mostly

on how we integrate soft
sensors inside our robots, specifically focusing on
soft optical sensing--

and then hybrid soft
rigid robotic mechanisms-- so robots that basically want to
combine the best of both worlds

when it comes to soft robotics,
which has many advantages. So you have soft materials that
can easily and safely interact

with the human body. But at the same time,
you have rigid components that allow these soft robots
to perform a little bit better

and have higher force
transmission, or stiffening, or even being able
to be folded down

into really tiny
compact configurations, and then use origami-inspired
mechanisms to unfold,

open up, pop up the robot, and
then perform a surgical task. So with soft continuum
robots, we've

been mostly focusing on
interventional bronchoscopy. And the reason why that
is that lung cancer

is the deadliest cancer today. It kills more patients than
prostate, breast, and colon

cancer combined. And so one of the
reasons why that is is that it is very difficult to
navigate to the peripheral part

of the lungs, so over here. And that's where approximately
80% of lung cancers are located.

And if you were able to
reach that position early on, and were able to
diagnose cancer early on,

and treat it early
on, of course, you would be able to achieve
a higher survival rate.

And so we've been working
on this robot that was actually published in Soft
Robotics a couple of years ago.

And I hope you can appreciate
how much small it is-- smaller it is with
respect to, for example,

a traditional
bronchoscope over here. You can even pass it
through the working channel of a traditional bronchoscope.

So this is actually the
smallest, most flexible, robotic bronchoscope these days.

It has a diameter of 2.4mm. And in this diameter, we
were able to integrate

one degree of freedom
banding actuation mechanism, a micro-camera,
and two working channels.

Two working channels are
beneficial because when you are at the surgical
target area, right here,

and you start poking
into the tissue and taking biopsies and so on,
of course, you'll have blood.

You'll have bleeding. And that, of course, gets
in front of your camera. So having two working channels
basically restores that ability

of doing multiple tasks. And so as you're
poking the tissue, you can probably
clean up the camera,

aspirate, and do some
something more useful without having to pass
instruments back and forth

and switch instruments with
only one working channel.

In the interest of time,
I won't go too much into the mechanical
characterizations of this robot and the workspace.

But really, what I want to talk
about is what we did in terms of ex-vivo tests-- so making
sure that we were able--

because this robot is
soft and it's so small, that we were still able to
perform tissue puncturing

to perform biopsies. But also, this system
has two working channels so that we could potentially
inject drugs into the lungs.

And so the reason why
we want to do that is that typically when you
go screening for lung cancer,
you take a biopsy. Then they analyze the biopsy. And the patient goes home.

And they are waiting a long
time to get the results. But then after a few
weeks, you hear back.

And if it's cancer, you have to
go back and do surgery again, right? That's not really
effective at all

because, at that time,
weeks, months will pass. And your lung cancer goes
maybe from stage 1 or 2

to stage 3 and 4. And maybe there is
nothing really more to do. Wouldn't it be great if we
have robotic technology that

would allow us to
take a patient in, have them being screened
for a biopsy procedure.

And then when they
wake up, your surgeon would tell you, well, bad news,
we found that you have cancer.

But the good news is that
we have already treated you. And you can come back in
six months or a year just

for follow-up so
that more lives would be saved at the end of the day. And so one thing
that we really were

excited about with this
soft robotic bronchoscope that we created is
the fact that it also

keeps vision sensing
integrated at all times during the surgical
procedure, which

is crucial to help surgeons
achieve a better [INAUDIBLE] biopsy and also
diagnostic yield.

So by using computer
vision algorithms, we were able to basically
create a robot that is

sort of like semi-autonomous. And so the surgeon can basically
use a graphic user interface

to command the robot to navigate
to a specific, preplanned location within the lungs.

And they would just click
where they want to go. The robot would align
into that location.

And then it can be pushed
and propelled forward. And the other thing,
of course, is,

by using computer
vision algorithms, we can help the robot
compensate for breathing motion.

And so you have to imagine that
the lungs are expanding quite a lot as you're
breathing and the surgeon

is performing biopsies. And so you have to be
sure that you're actually puncturing where the tumor is.

And so compensating
for that type of motion is very important for us.

And so taking a step
forward, what we did was actually we've been creating
these soft miniaturized robots--

like I said, compensating
for breathing motion and taking biopsies. But really, as you're
scaling soft robots down,

the amount of force
that you actually can output through these robots
is also scaling down quite

substantially. And so we came up with
other interesting questions about, for example,
well, how are

we going to be able to make
sure that this robot is capable of puncturing
through very effectively?

How is it going to be
controllable within the lungs as it's performing
the procedure?

And so over here, this paper
that we published very recently this year, the soft robot
is capable of deploying

soft robotic actuators to anchor
itself through the surrounding bronchi anatomy.

And that helps the
robot be more accurate. But at the same time,
it also helps the robot

sustain a higher
level of force output as we are trying
to target a biopsy.

And so over here,
basically, I'm going to skip quickly maybe
through some of these things. But over here, we were
able to demonstrate

that we were able to achieve
pretty high output forces which are way above the range
of the surgical tasks

that we want to do as we are
performing biopsy procedures. And we were also
able to demonstrate

we have created origami-inspired
soft robotic mechanisms that

can help the surgeon
control the needle deployment inside the
lungs to take biopsies such

as, for example,
in this case, we have a needle attached to a
soft robotic origami-inspired actuator that can
basically command

the puncturing of the tissue. And next steps
over here are going to be integrating also
steering because sometimes when

you are at a location when
you want to take a biopsy, the tumor is located
maybe close by. And so you have to achieve
pretty sharp bending angles

to make sure that you can
puncture your way through. And so in vitro test, we have a
3D printed model of a bronchi,

where we basically have our
robot navigating to this point. The robot is stabilizing itself
around the surrounding anatomy

so that it can be more
accurate and puncture its way through the lungs.

Over here, this is a
gelatin model of the lungs. We demonstrated that we are
still able to steer the needle,

in case that's necessary. Of course, we will have
also intraoperative imaging CT scans as we are
performing the procedure.

And then we're able to deploy
the needle inside the lungs, hopefully to get
where the tumor is.

And over here, the
dye that you're seeing is just a simulated
dye that we use

to see to make sure that
we're actually puncturing through the lung tissue. So switching gears
a little bit, I

want to talk a little bit
about soft robotic skins, soft reactive skins. And like I mentioned
in my introduction,

these are soft robots
that you can wrap around any type of medical
instrumentation to robotize it.

So they are dense with
soft sensors and actuators. And in this case, these
are soft, optical sensors.

My student is
pressing upon them. And as you can see,
the soft sensor is triggering the inflation
of a soft robotic actuator.

The way that we
are realizing these is just basically we are
using different types of soft elastomers,
as you can see here.

And by playing with
the refractive index of these soft elastomers, we're
capable of transmitting light

through these waveguides
that you see over here. And so transmitting
light through--

and then if you press
on these sensors, the sensor response will change. And you're able to track
pressure, forces, banding,

and a variety of other things
that I'm going to talk about. And one application
that we had in mind here was interventional
colonoscopy.

So sometimes, in
colonoscopy, as you're pushing the colonoscope
inside the colon to navigate,

you might have excessive
force concentration. And of course, if
you're a healthy person, it's not too much
of a huge deal.

But if you are not and you
already have some comorbidities, this can potentially cause
perforations, bleeding.

If you are located in
a place in the world where you don't have
access to anesthesia or good, large
hospitals, you might

want to have
something like this, where you have a soft robot that
allows the surgeon to perform

a gentler, safer procedure. My dad actually
recently underwent

a colonoscopy procedure. My family lives in
the south of Tuscany in Italy in a really small town.

They don't have
any anesthesiology in their hospital. So he underwent this
colonoscopy procedure.

And it was so painful for him. And he's a tough guy. And it was so painful
for him that he couldn't

withstand the procedure. And so when I told
him about the research that we do in my
lab, of course, he was like, when can I get your
instrument to do this procedure?

Unfortunately, not really soon. But anyway, so what we do
is basically, like I said,

use these sensors to
trigger the inflation of these soft robotic actuators,
sort of like air bags, if you will, that can help the
surgeon distribute these forces

and pressures and hopefully
have a gentler procedure. I want to show you this
in vitro simulated test

that we did where this is
a model of a colon, where we basically show
that, if we apply

too much force within
our colonoscope, the soft robotic actuators
are capable of deploying.

And we are also
capable of, like I said, if we have a very
treated amount of force,

by triggering the soft
robotic actuators, we can distribute that
around a larger area

to make the procedure a little
bit more gentle for the patient. And then we took
this a step further

by amplifying that haptic
feedback back to the surgeon. So this is the soft robotic
sleeve that we have over here.

And as we are
pressing on it, we are returning that
haptic sensation back to the surgeon as
they are wearing

a soft robotic glove over here. And we were able to
test this together with a surgeon that is
collaborating with us at Brigham

and Women's Hospital. This person especially
is an expert surgeon.

We are hoping to start testing
on novice people as well. But the goal of this is
really providing that level

of extra awareness for
the clinician, such that they can be able to
perform better procedures.

And then again, for more
of a trained person, you would be able to still see
an improvement in the procedure.

We measured the NASA task
load for our surgeon. And we're able to see that the
mental and physical workload was

diminishing for them as they
were performing that procedure. But you can imagine
that even if you were taking somebody's
novice, that

would help them be more trained
and be able to perform a better procedure in the long run.

So these technologies
can not only help people,
patients, and surgeons as they are performing
the procedures,

but even can help
during training. Regarding haptic feedback,
we've been focusing not only

on interventional
colonoscopy and the project that I just talked about,
which is funded by NIH,

but also we are tackling other
aspects of haptic feedback in remote palpation or
robotic-assisted palpation.

So by using soft robotics
and microfluidics, we are able to manufacture
really tiny soft actuators that

can be positioned at the
fingertips, over here, and integrated in soft
robotic wearable gloves.

And what we do is
basically, again, by using soft optical sensors--

in this case, this is
so easy and super cheap to manufacture because these
are literally flexible tubes

that we are integrating
in our sensors. And they are very inexpensive
and easy to manufacture.

And over here,
again, we are showing how we are using
microfluidics to create our soft robotic actuators.

And so what we do
is basically we have this soft sensor
that is mounted

at the end effector of a robot. And it is basically
palpating a tissue model,

where we have embedded a tumor,
so like a higher stiffness

material in here. And when we are basically
sensing that tumor,

these actuators are going to
return that haptic feedback back to the surgeon. And this is a paper
actually that we currently

have under review. But again, there is
so much more that you can do with this soft
optical sensing technology

that we have developed. And I just want to touch upon
quickly two other applications that we are looking into,
which are soft optical sensors
for shape and contact tracking.

So in this case, this is
a soft continuum robot with a module over here that
has multiple degrees of freedom

and a soft robotic gripper
mounted at the tip. And we are able
to not only track

the shape of the
robot and the gripper, but also detect if the
robot is contacting

objects and interacting with
the surrounding environment. So how do we do that? This is the module.

It has soft optical
sensors embedded inside these ones over here. It's only one sensor
at the gripper.

And by using
roughness tuning, we can tune the optical
properties of that sensor.

So we are roughening the
tip of our mold over here. And that roughness
actually translates

into the soft
optical sensor such that basically
we're able to have,

contact. And so as you can see here,
when our gripper is moving,

we're getting the response that
we're supposed to be getting. But then as it's
touching an object, we are getting a different
type of response.

And we can track that contact. And the cool thing about that
is that you can track these two

different inputs. And how you do
that is basically-- I want to show you
a live plot of this.

So as the gripper is
deploying and opening, you have this type of response.

But then if you have an object
placed at the gripper jaws, you basically have a
different type of response

which basically gets
you that information that you're looking for, whether
or not there has been contact,

with just one sensor integrated. The cool thing
about this robot is

we're looking into
potentially having it applied in minimally invasive
surgical applications-- so

for example, a scenario
like this in laparoscopy. And so we were
able to test this.

This is a recent work that we
currently have on the review. We were able to test this in
like a pick and place pack

transfer task scenario,
where we pick up an object and we move it to
point A to point B.

And recently, we've
been not only capable of tracking the shape of
the gripper and the robot

and returning information
about whether or not there has been contact,
but we are also able to track and
sense how much force

we are applying onto
the object, which is crucial in applications,
again, like minimally

invasive surgery. But you could think of any
other type of application like environmental exploration,
any type of really application

in robotics where you would
benefit from having a really sneaky snake-like robot to
manipulate the environment,

and grasp objects, and so on. And then, again, just one
really quick other thing

that we can do with
this technology of soft optical sensing-- we have been looking
into other types

of clinical applications
such as, for example, bleeding detection. This is very important in
applications like colonoscopy,

for example, where you have a
camera located at the distal end of the instrument.

But you don't really have
any other information about sensors, any other
sensors along the length

of the endoscope. And so you don't have any
information about what's going on in the back.

And so sometimes,
like I said, if you're applying too much
force or the patient has any other comorbidities,
you might get bleeding.

And you end up knowing that
there has been bleeding actually only when you're pulling
away the instrument, right?

And so we've been looking
at soft optical sensors that can detect bleeding. And you could think
about having them

distributed along the length of
your tool, of your colonoscope. And so over here, we have
a soft optical sensor,

a U-shaped soft optical sensor. And by using
microfluidics, we're capable of basically picking
up blood that has been--

that is in the colon. The blood will enter our
microfluidic channel. And the soft optical sensor
here will detect that

just by measuring the
change in refractive index within the microfluidic channel.

So the way that this
works is, again, you have light going
through this waveguide.

And when this is analog
blood, synthetic blood. And when blood is passing
through this microchannel,

the sensor will
basically pick it up. And the cool thing
about this is that we were able to
demonstrate that we are

capable of measuring different
concentrations of blood. And so based on the sensor
response and the bandwidth,

you can track whether there
has been a minor bleeding or there is a
hemorrhage going on. And so you can alert
surgeons about that.

We are able to differentiate
between blood and other types of fluids within the
body-- so for example,

in the colon, gastric fluid. And so we know how the
sensor is going to respond.

And in the future, we're
hoping to use this technology as a biosensor for
other types of maybe

diagnosis of other morbidities,
other illnesses within the colon or in other locations
of the body.

This is an in-vitro test in
a simulated colon environment where we were able to validate
our sensor working and picking

up blood over here. And we're hoping-- actually
[? Aring, ?] my student,

is currently doing ex-vivo
tests on explanted column

models with our collaborators. And hopefully over the
summer and in the fall, we're planning on
doing in vivo studies

on this, so in live,
actual, porcine models. So very excited about that.

And then I want to switch
gears one last time and talk about hybrid
soft foldable robots.

So like I mentioned, over
in this area of research that we currently have going
on in the Material Robotics

Lab, what we are
looking at is combining the best of both
worlds when it comes to soft robotics for
surgical applications

and rigid origami-inspired
mechanisms. And so these are some
of my past works,

where I was working on basically
endoscopic robotic add-ons-- so robots that you
could put around

the tip of an endoscope
and they would lie flat as you are navigating
your way, for example,

in the anatomy, and so
not hamper navigation of colonoscopes, for example.

But then when you reach
the surgical target area, they would unfold, pop
up, and help perform

some level of surgical task-- and so for example,
in this case, expanding and anchoring
the colonoscope tip

to enable better force
application, better force output during procedures and
all sorts of other things.

What is interesting about this
is that, as you probably know, soft materials and
rigid materials

don't interface really well. And so if you want to
build a robot out of this, you need to be very
cognizant about how you're

going to be bonding these
materials together, how are they not going to delaminate. And so we basically developed
manufacturing technologies based

on soft lithography, laser
precision micromachining, and chemical
surface modification

borrowed from, again,
soft lithography realm to create mechanisms
that are super tiny.

These are my fingers over here. And by using
microfluidics, we are able to have these soft
rigid actuators move around.

They can do a pretty
large range of motion. And also, we're able
of embedding sensing--

so achieving
proprioceptive actuation. For example, in this case,
we have a capacitive sensor.

And as our soft micro
actuator is expanding, we're capable of tracking the
motion of this robotic actuator.

But you could potentially
also think about for sensing and other
types of sensing again.

So one of the things that we
did with this technology was developing, like I
mentioned, robotic add-ons--

so for example, multi
degrees of freedom robotic arms that
could be placed at the tip of a colonoscope
to perform tissue manipulation

and especially one thing that
is called tissue retraction. So in this case,
over here, you can

see that we have a
vacuum gripper as the end effector of the robot.

And the arm is basically
helping lifting this tissue up so that we can perform
tissue biopsy and so on.

So that was part of my previous
work as a postdoc at Harvard. And I was approached
by a neurosurgeon when

I moved to BU who was very
excited about this technology and told me, oh,
can we do something

for narrow surgical procedures? On a daily basis, I am trying
to access tumors located

in a very deep position
within the brain. And like I mentioned,
they can reach that tumor.

But then post-operatively,
they have complications for the patient, right? And the reason why they
have these complications

is that basically they're using
stainless steel spatulas that

are pretty rigid. And they have no sensing, of
course, embedded onto them. And so really, the
procedure looks brutal.

These instruments are
medieval, if you will, right? So the surgeon doesn't really
have much information about

how much force they are
applying onto the tissue. Why is there not a
robotic technology that can make these procedures
more safer, I would say?

So we have developed this
soft origami-inspired robotic

retractor that can
basically squeeze into a really tiny
configuration and be inserted

inside the brain, bypassing
through your nostrils or maybe a birdhole in the
skull, and then create

a working channel for
the surgeons to operate, where they can
insert instruments

and they can see the tumor
that is located inside. So of course, we were able
to characterize the system.

But what's most important
is that we validated it in an in vitro simulation
procedure, where

we were able to see that,
of course, the robot, because it's soft
and it has multiple--

like a larger surface, it can
interact with brain tissue in a safer way and exert
forces at a level that

is more controlled
than traditional rigid instrumentation. And so that was something that
we were really excited about.

And hopefully, we're
moving forward. And right now, actually-- oops. And right now actually,
we are looking

at integrating sensors
on this structure too, to not only measure the
forces in a continuous way

throughout the procedure. But also, what we
want to look at is integrating sensors that
can track, for example, brain

activity during the procedure. And this is really
exciting because you can have really robot--

you can really have a
robot that is interacting with the human and the
tissue and return information

about, for example,
physiological entities, physiological information
to the surgeon

as they are doing
their procedure, and hopefully be even
more safe when it comes to performing neurosurgery.

And last but not
least, I just want to mention quickly recent work
that we currently are doing

on soft rigid robotic systems. And this is work by
my PhD student, Bryan,

who has developed a really
interesting manufacturing technology, again based on
laser precision micromachining

and chemical surface
modification of soft materials, to make sure that he's
able of integrating

these soft
origami-inspired actuators inside origami-rigid structures.

And the way he's doing that
is by having everything-- so there is no manual assembly
of these soft actuators.

Everything is really already
thought about as a batch manufacturing procedure.

So you can scale these
down as much as you like. You can easily assemble them
pretty quickly without error,

without human error. And the cool thing about that is
that you can integrate, again, sensing.

In this case, we're looking
at ionic resistive sensing. And we are using the fluid that
we are using for actuation also

as a sensing medium. And so again, combining
all the pieces of a puzzle when it comes
to robotic actuation,

sensing, and controls. And Bryan was able to develop
different types of joints

and degrees of freedom. So over here, we
have linear rotation,

rotor translational combined. And this is the
response of the sensor. And because these are,
again hybrid robots,

we can use the benefits
of both worlds. And so this goes back into
basically having rigid robots.

And we all know how to predict
the motion of rigid robots and model them, right? And so when we are able of
doing that, we can track,

predict their position. We have sensors
embedded that return us every type of
